description: Creating a task force on housing cost driver analysis.

original.text:
H-0079.1
HOUSE BILL 1108
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Klicker, Peterson, Barkis, Ybarra, Low, Leavitt, Schmidt, Eslick, Penner, Connors, Paul, Ramel, Jacobsen, Shavers, Burnett, Rude, Keaton, Obras, Timmons, Wylie, Caldier, Barnard, Rule, Nance, Berg, and Bernbaum
Prefiled 12/20/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Housing.
AN ACT Relating to creating a task force on housing cost driver analysis; creating a new section; and providing an expiration date.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 1. (1)(a) A legislative task force on housing cost driver analysis is established, with members as provided in this subsection.
(i) The president of the senate shall appoint one member from each of the two largest caucuses of the senate.
(ii) The speaker of the house of representatives shall appoint one member from each of the two largest caucuses of the house of representatives.
(iii) The president of the senate and the speaker of the house of representatives jointly shall appoint the following members:
(A) Two economists with expertise in the economic disciplines most relevant to the issue of housing cost drivers;
(B) One member representing nonprofit housing developers;
(C) One member representing for-profit housing developers;
(D) One member representing builders;
(E) One member representing labor;
(F) One member representing realtors;
(G) One member representing cities;
(H) One member representing counties;
(I) One member representing tenants;
(J) One member representing landlords;
(K) One member representing home mortgage lenders;
(L) One member representing multifamily lenders;
(M) One member representing utility providers;
(N) One member representing public housing authorities;
(O) One member representing the Washington state housing finance commission;
(P) One member from a statewide association representing business; and
(Q) One member from an organization representing architects.
(b) The task force shall choose its cochairs from among its legislative membership. The legislative membership shall convene the initial meeting of the task force.
(2) The task force shall research, analyze, and determine the primary cost drivers for housing in Washington state.
(3) Staff support for the task force must be provided by the senate committee services and the house of representatives office of program research.
(4) The task force, in completing the duties prescribed by this section, shall solicit and consider information and perspectives provided by the affordable housing advisory board and persons and entities with relevant interest and expertise.
(5) Legislative members of the task force are reimbursed for travel expenses in accordance with RCW 44.04.120. Nonlegislative members are not entitled to be reimbursed for travel expenses if they are elected officials or are participating on behalf of an employer, governmental entity, or other organization. Any reimbursement for other nonlegislative members is subject to chapter 43.03 RCW.
(6) The expenses of the task force must be paid jointly by the senate and the house of representatives. Task force expenditures are subject to approval by the senate facilities and operations committee and the house of representatives executive rules committee, or their successor committees.
(7) The task force shall report its findings and recommendations to the appropriate committees of the legislature by December 1, 2026.
(8) This section expires June 1, 2027.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The purpose of this bill is to establish a legislative task force in Washington State that will analyze the primary cost drivers affecting housing. The aim is to gather information and insights from various stakeholders in the housing sector to better understand and potentially mitigate housing costs. The task force will research and report their findings and recommendations to the legislature by December 1, 2026.

Key Provisions

Task Force Composition

  • The task force will consist of:
    • Members appointed by the president of the senate from the two largest caucuses of the senate.
    • Members appointed by the speaker of the house of representatives from the two largest caucuses of the house.
    • Joint appointments by the president and speaker for various stakeholders, including:
      • Economists with expertise in housing costs.
      • Representatives from nonprofit and for-profit housing developers.
      • Builders, labor representatives, realtors, city and county representatives, tenants, landlords, and members from financial institutions and utility providers.

Responsibilities

  • The task force is tasked with:
    • Researching and analyzing the main cost drivers for housing in Washington State.
    • Soliciting information from the affordable housing advisory board and other relevant parties.

Operations and Support

  • The task force will receive staff support from senate committee services and the house of representatives office of program research.
  • Legislative members will be reimbursed for travel expenses, while nonlegislative members may not receive reimbursement unless they qualify under specified circumstances.
  • The expenses of the task force will be financed jointly by the senate and house, subject to approval from designated committees.

Reporting and Expiration

  • The task force must present its findings and recommendations to legislative committees by December 1, 2026.
  • The provisions outlined in this section will expire on June 1, 2027.

subDocuments.description: Substitute House Bill 1108 as Recommended by Housing

original.text:
H-0845.1
SUBSTITUTE HOUSE BILL 1108
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByHouse Housing (originally sponsored by Representatives Klicker, Peterson, Barkis, Ybarra, Low, Leavitt, Schmidt, Eslick, Penner, Connors, Paul, Ramel, Jacobsen, Shavers, Burnett, Rude, Keaton, Obras, Timmons, Wylie, Caldier, Barnard, Rule, Nance, Berg, and Bernbaum)
READ FIRST TIME 01/27/25.
AN ACT Relating to creating a task force on housing cost driver analysis; creating a new section; and providing an expiration date.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 1. (1)(a) A legislative task force on housing cost driver analysis is established, with members as provided in this subsection.
(i) The president of the senate shall appoint one member from each of the two largest caucuses of the senate.
(ii) The speaker of the house of representatives shall appoint one member from each of the two largest caucuses of the house of representatives.
(iii) The president of the senate and the speaker of the house of representatives jointly shall appoint the following members:
(A) Two economists with expertise in the economic disciplines most relevant to the issue of housing cost drivers;
(B) One member representing nonprofit developers of rental housing;
(C) One member representing nonprofit developers of housing for homeownership;
(D) One member representing for-profit housing developers;
(E) One member representing builders;
(F) One member representing a statewide organization representing the building trades labor;
(G) One member representing realtors;
(H) One member representing cities;
(I) One member representing counties;
(J) One member representing tenants;
(K) One member representing landlords who provide at least 10 rental housing units;
(L) One member representing landlords who provide no more than two rental housing units;
(M) One member from a statewide association representing real estate appraisers;
(N) One member representing home mortgage lenders;
(O) One member representing multifamily lenders;
(P) One member representing utility providers;
(Q) One member representing public housing authorities;
(R) One member representing the Washington state housing finance commission;
(S) One member from a statewide association representing business; and
(T) One member from an organization representing architects.
(b) The task force shall choose its cochairs from among its legislative membership. The legislative membership shall convene the initial meeting of the task force.
(2) The task force shall research, analyze, and determine the primary cost drivers for homeownership and rental housing in Washington state.
(3) Staff support for the task force must be provided by the senate committee services and the house of representatives office of program research.
(4) The task force, in completing the duties prescribed by this section, shall solicit and consider information and perspectives provided by the affordable housing advisory board and persons and entities with relevant interest and expertise.
(5) Legislative members of the task force are reimbursed for travel expenses in accordance with RCW 44.04.120. Nonlegislative members are not entitled to be reimbursed for travel expenses if they are elected officials or are participating on behalf of an employer, governmental entity, or other organization. Any reimbursement for other nonlegislative members is subject to chapter 43.03 RCW.
(6) The expenses of the task force must be paid jointly by the senate and the house of representatives. Task force expenditures are subject to approval by the senate facilities and operations committee and the house of representatives executive rules committee, or their successor committees.
(7) The task force shall report its findings and recommendations to the appropriate committees of the legislature by December 1, 2026.
(8) This section expires June 1, 2027.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The edits made to the proposed legislature bill regarding the creation of a task force on housing cost driver analysis aimed to clarify the specifics of the membership and focus of the task force. The main change from the original version was the more detailed categorization of members representing various sectors in housing, including both nonprofit and for-profit developers. By identifying specific types of nonprofit developers and landlord categories, the bill now provides a clearer representation of stakeholders in the housing market. This change is intended to enhance the task force's ability to effectively analyze and address the diverse factors driving housing costs in Washington state.

Key Changes

Membership Composition

  • Changed “one member representing nonprofit housing developers” to “one member representing nonprofit developers of rental housing” and “one member representing nonprofit developers of housing for homeownership”.
  • Updated “one member representing for-profit housing developers” to simply “one member representing for-profit housing developers”.
  • Changed “one member representing labor” to “one member representing a statewide organization representing the building trades labor”.
  • Split “one member representing landlords” into two separate categories:
    • “one member representing landlords who provide at least 10 rental housing units”.
    • “one member representing landlords who provide no more than two rental housing units”.
  • Added “one member from a statewide association representing real estate appraisers” to ensure expertise in property valuation is included in the task force.

Focus of the Task Force

  • Revised the task force's focus from determining the primary cost drivers for housing in general to specifically addressing the drivers for “homeownership and rental housing in Washington state”. This adjustment aims to ensure comprehensive analysis relevant to both aspects of housing.

These changes strengthen the task force's capacity to understand and tackle the complexity of housing costs, ensuring that various perspectives are represented.

subDocuments.name: 1108-S2

original.text:
H-1781.1
SECOND SUBSTITUTE HOUSE BILL 1108
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByHouse Appropriations (originally sponsored by Representatives Klicker, Peterson, Barkis, Ybarra, Low, Leavitt, Schmidt, Eslick, Penner, Connors, Paul, Ramel, Jacobsen, Shavers, Burnett, Rude, Keaton, Obras, Timmons, Wylie, Caldier, Barnard, Rule, Nance, Berg, and Bernbaum)
READ FIRST TIME 02/28/25.
AN ACT Relating to creating a task force on housing cost driver analysis; creating new sections; and providing an expiration date.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 1. (1)(a) A legislative task force on housing cost driver analysis is established, with members as provided in this subsection.
(i) The president of the senate shall appoint one member from each of the two largest caucuses of the senate.
(ii) The speaker of the house of representatives shall appoint one member from each of the two largest caucuses of the house of representatives.
(iii) The president of the senate and the speaker of the house of representatives jointly shall appoint the following members:
(A) Two economists with expertise in the economic disciplines most relevant to the issue of housing cost drivers;
(B) One member representing nonprofit developers of rental housing;
(C) One member representing nonprofit developers of housing for homeownership;
(D) One member representing for-profit housing developers;
(E) One member representing builders;
(F) One member representing a statewide organization representing the building trades labor;
(G) One member representing realtors;
(H) One member representing cities;
(I) One member representing counties;
(J) One member representing tenants;
(K) One member representing landlords who provide at least 10 rental housing units;
(L) One member representing landlords who provide no more than two rental housing units;
(M) One member from a statewide association representing real estate appraisers;
(N) One member representing home mortgage lenders;
(O) One member representing multifamily lenders;
(P) One member representing utility providers;
(Q) One member representing public housing authorities;
(R) One member representing the Washington state housing finance commission;
(S) One member from a statewide association representing business; and
(T) One member from an organization representing architects.
(b) The task force shall choose its cochairs from among its legislative membership. The legislative membership shall convene the initial meeting of the task force. The task force may not meet more than three times, and all task force meetings must be held virtually.
(2) The task force shall research, analyze, and determine the primary cost drivers for homeownership and rental housing in Washington state.
(3) Staff support for the task force must be provided by the senate committee services and the house of representatives office of program research.
(4) The task force, in completing the duties prescribed by this section, shall solicit and consider information and perspectives provided by the affordable housing advisory board and persons and entities with relevant interest and expertise.
(5) Legislative members of the task force are reimbursed for travel expenses in accordance with RCW 44.04.120. Nonlegislative members are not entitled to be reimbursed for travel expenses if they are elected officials or are participating on behalf of an employer, governmental entity, or other organization. Any reimbursement for other nonlegislative members is subject to chapter 43.03 RCW.
(6) The expenses of the task force must be paid jointly by the senate and the house of representatives. Task force expenditures are subject to approval by the senate facilities and operations committee and the house of representatives executive rules committee, or their successor committees.
(7) The task force shall report its findings and recommendations to the appropriate committees of the legislature by December 1, 2026.
(8) This section expires June 1, 2027.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 2. If specific funding for the purposes of this act, referencing this act by bill or chapter number, is not provided by June 30, 2025, in the omnibus appropriations act, this act is null and void.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The edits in the proposed legislation aim to enhance the structure and specificity of the task force on housing cost driver analysis. The revised version introduces additional sections and clarifies the responsibilities and composition of the task force, ensuring a more detailed approach to understand housing cost issues in Washington state. This includes a focus on both homeownership and rental housing, as well as a mechanism for the act to become null and void if specific funding is not appropriated. The changes are intended to improve the effectiveness and accountability of the task force.

Key Changes

Task Force Composition

  • The representation of various stakeholders has been modified:
    • Nonprofit Developers:
      • Shift from a general title to specific roles:
      • Nonprofit developers of rental housing.
      • Nonprofit developers of housing for homeownership.
    • Landlords:
      • Divided into two categories based on the number of units they provide:
      • One member representing landlords who provide at least 10 rental housing units.
      • One member representing landlords who provide no more than two rental housing units.
    • Labor Representation:
      • Clarified to involve a statewide organization representing the building trades labor.

Task Force Functionality

  • Added an operational limit on the task force's meeting frequency:
    • The task force may not meet more than three times, and all meetings must be held virtually.

Research Scope

  • Expanded focus for the task force's research:
    • The task force is now responsible for determining the primary cost drivers for both homeownership and rental housing, rather than solely housing in general.

New Section

  • Introduction of a new section (Sec. 2):
    • If specific funding for the purposes of the act is not provided by June 30, 2025, the act will be null and void. This sets a clear condition for the act's validity based on financial appropriations.
